                    ### Question
                    A three year old child is brought to the emergency depament having just ingested a large overdose of an antihistaminic drug. This drug is a weak base capable of entering most tissues including the brain. On physical examination the hea rate is 100/ minute, blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg and the respiratory rate is 20/ minute. In this case of poisoning:

                    ### Options
                    opa. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent
opb. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NaHCO 3, an alkalinizing agent
opc. More of the drug would be ionized at blood pH than at stomach pH
opd. Absorption of the drug would be faster from the stomach than from the small intestine.

### Enhanced Information (For Contextual Support):
In cases of poisoning with a weak base antihistaminic drug, urinary excretion can be influenced by urine pH. Administering NH4Cl, an acidifying agent, would lower urine pH, leading to increased ionization of the weak base and thus enhancing urinary excretion due to reduced reabsorption. Conversely, administering NaHCO3, an alkalinizing agent, would raise urine pH, resulting in decreased ionization and increased reabsorption, thereby reducing urinary excretion. Regarding the ionization of the drug, at blood pH (approximately 7.4), the weak base is less ionized compared to stomach pH (which is more acidic), meaning more of the drug is ionized in the stomach than in the blood. Lastly, absorption of weak bases is generally faster in the small intestine due to its higher pH compared to the stomach, where the drug is more ionized and less readily absorbed. Therefore, the correct options are: (a) Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NH4Cl, and (c) More of the drug would be ionized at stomach pH than at blood pH.
